sindurasaraswathi:

For simplicity, let’s assume p(\\tau) and q(\\tau) are independent.

I do like the idea of a statistical analysis here, seems like a very good idea (btw did you find any earlier literature on the problem? I feel like there have definitely been papers that discussed multisignature and thresholds in various ways, but I don’t remember much).

But about the quoted text: I was already wondering this myself, before I got to that sentence Do you think it’s actually true? It seems intuitively that it shouldn’t be.

Edit: ah I actually got to the end and saw there is a paper You footnote in the paper that there may be a dependence “if the attacker knows something about the user’s behavior”. But aren’t p and q related in a more fundamental way, like p represents how likely I am to “break in” to my own system, q represents how likely “someone else” is (but “someone else” needs to be formalized pretty carefully in threshold systems!); isn’t it obvious that they’re not independent, even if they are radically different probabilities?
